A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Transposition to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a transposition, as defined, refers to a specific type of permutation in the context of group theory, specifically a 2-cycle. This definition is self-contained and does not inherently require any operation to be associative. It simply describes a permutation that swaps two elements and leaves all others fixed.

The associative law, on the other hand, pertains to the property of a binary operation within a set. It states that the grouping of operations does not affect the outcome. This law is relevant in the context of operations like addition or multiplication on numbers, or more generally, any binary operation on a set that needs to satisfy this property for structural reasons.

In the context of the definitions provided, the definition of a transposition (a 2-cycle) does not depend on or require the associative property of any operation. It is purely a description of a particular kind of permutation and does not involve the composition of operations in a way that would necessitate the associative law.
